step1.sentence: By launching their product two weeks early, the startup managed to steal a march on their biggest competitor.

step2.story: Clara had been working on her business proposal in secret for months. On the morning of the big investor meeting, she arrived early and presented first, stealing a march on her rival who had expected to go before her. The look of surprise on his face was all the confirmation she needed.

step3.story: The tech conference was the most anticipated event of the year, and every major company had been preparing their announcements for months. Marcus, the head of product at a mid-sized firm, had quietly been coordinating a surprise reveal scheduled for the opening morning. While the industry giants were still setting up their booths, his team took the stage and unveiled a groundbreaking feature that no one had seen coming. By the time the larger competitors were ready to present, the buzz was already everywhere—Marcus had effectively stolen a march on all of them. Journalists flooded his team's booth, and by noon his company's name was trending across every tech publication. It was a calculated gamble that paid off entirely because of the element of surprise.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 행군(march)을 몰래 훔쳐간다는 뜻으로, 상대방이 알기 전에 먼저 움직인다는 의미입니다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 경쟁자나 상대방보다 먼저 행동하여 유리한 위치를 선점하는 상황에서 사용됩니다. 비즈니스, 스포츠, 정치 등 경쟁이 있는 모든 맥락에서 폭넓게 쓰입니다.
meaning.etymologyKo: 군사 용어에서 유래했습니다. 과거 전쟁에서 'march'는 군대가 하루에 이동하는 거리를 의미했으며, 적이 모르는 사이에 야간에 군대를 이동시켜 전략적 우위를 선점하는 행위를 'steal a march'라고 불렀습니다.
meaning.nuanceKo: 단순히 빠르다는 의미보다는 전략적이고 의도적인 선제 행동을 강조합니다. 상대가 미처 대비하지 못한 상황에서 기습적으로 앞서간다는 뉘앙스가 강하며, 다소 교활하거나 영리하다는 느낌을 줄 수 있습니다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: She stole a march on her colleagues by submitting the report a day early.
meaning.shortExampleKo: 그녀는 보고서를 하루 일찍 제출하여 동료들보다 선수를 쳤다.
